column1: #FORMAT=WebAnno TSV 3.2
#T_SP=webanno.custom.Referent|entity|infstat
#T_RL=webanno.custom.Coref|type|BT_webanno.custom.Referent
#Text=Facilitate a Group
#Text=A group facilitator ’s job is important , because they encourage communication without strongly influencing the discussion .
#Text=Successful group leaders can control and enhance a group with good planning , open-ended questions and positive reinforcement .
#Text=Steps
#Text=Organizing a Group
#Text=Announce your group .
#Text=Choose the best possible mode of communication to reach anyone who might be interested .
#Text=Try multiple channels if possible .
#Text=If you are organizing a work group , use company email .
#Text=If you are organizing a school group , ask for telephone numbers or emails .
#Text=Also , research a school LISTSERV to encourage new membership .
#Text=If you are hosting a church group , make sure the meeting time is in the church bulletin .
#Text=If you are starting a support group , post the information at hospitals , online and in counselor/doctor offices .
#Text=Research possible topics ahead of time .
#Text=Look online and in books for ideas on what topics to choose .
#Text=If you are leading a work group , get all the research and reports sent out a few days ahead of time so that everyone can be on the same page for the meeting .
#Text=Learn time management skills before you facilitate a group .
#Text=Starting and ending meetings require an outspoken person who will keep track of time and any remaining agenda items .
#Text=Wear a watch and refer back to it occasionally to make sure you are on track .
#Text=Announce the start and end time in your communication with group members .
#Text=Also , consider announcing topics and the time structure so that members can adequately prepare .
#Text=One important structure to announce is whether it is an open group and whether the group has “ cross-talk . ”
#Text=This means that the group can discuss , rather than just sharing an opinion when it is their turn .
#Text=Mentally prepare yourself for facilitation .
#Text=It can be exhausting to lead a group , especially for professional and emotional topics .
#Text=Get a good night sleep and do some deep breathing techniques before you start the group meeting .
#Text=Set up an environment that facilitates discussion .
#Text=Sitting in a circle is a classic approach , because no one is left out .
#Text=Move chairs into a circle before anyone else arrives .
#Text=Avoid a “ classroom ” approach .
#Text=If everyone must see you , but ca n’t see each other , you will be more of an authority figure and have a harder time encouraging discussion between group members .
#Text=Practice neutrality .
#Text=It is your job to encourage participation without affecting the outcome .
#Text=If you are an opinionated person , practice holding your tongue in political or opinionated discussions .
#Text=Starting Discussions
#Text=Introduce yourself .
#Text=Keep it brief , but announce your qualifications or interest in the success of the group .
#Text=Aim to keep the introduction between one and two minutes long .
#Text=State the group rules if they are necessary for the function of the group .
#Text=Groups like Alcoholics Anonymous have steps and traditions that are to be read at the beginning of each meeting .
#Text=Do n’t go overboard with rules , as they might restrict expression in the group .
#Text=Announce the purpose of the meeting .
#Text=If there are desired outcomes or agenda points , review them now .
#Text=Set times if necessary .
#Text=Adjust the structure of group discussion based on how many members you have .
#Text=If you are leading a small group , you may be able to go around in a circle ( Round Robin ) so that everyone has a chance to speak .
#Text=If you are leading a large group , you may need to encourage the raising of hands or free speaking .
#Text=Announce the structure of the group before you start , so that everyone has the same expectations .
#Text=Do n’t fall into “ teaching behaviors . ”
#Text=This is when you begin to answer questions , state facts or speak frequently .
#Text=You are serving as a neutral party , not a teacher .
#Text=Facilitating Discussion
#Text=Ask open-ended questions .
#Text=Avoid asking questions to the group with yes or no answers .
#Text=If they must be yes/no answers , ask group members to elaborate on why that is the answer .
#Text=Continue with follow-up questions if discussion does n’t start immediately .
#Text=Good follow-up questions include “ How does that change the way you feel about X , Y , Z ? ” and “ How do you think that applies to other issues that we are discussing ? ”
#Text=Break the group into smaller groups for projects or intimate discussion .
#Text=If you are afraid that the group is too large to encourage adequate participation , small group work is a good way to encourage everyone in a group to interact .
#Text=Give positive reinforcement .
#Text=Encourage positive interactions .
#Text=Thank people for their contributions .
#Text=Do n’t be critical .
#Text=Even if your group is created for critiques , criticism should be only give in small doses .
#Text=Start each comment with positive reinforcement .
#Text=Suggest an energizer activity if you have a long meeting .
#Text=Between subjects , encourage people to play a game , watch a related YouTube clip or get up and move around .
#Text=Deal with disagreements by finding common ground .
#Text=It is your job as the group leader to recognize potential arguments and try to move on in a productive way .
#Text=Say , “ It sounds like we have a difference of opinion . ”
#Text=“ Different points of view are encouraged in our group . ”
#Text=“ It sounds like you both feel passionate about this . ”
#Text=“ It seems that we can agree on X , Y , Z. ”
#Text=Encourage other people to lead future discussions .
#Text=This is a good way for people to feel joint ownership of a group and its goals .
#Text=Create an evaluation process .
#Text=Ask people to take a questionnaire or discuss changes or issues wit you .
#Text=Things You 'll Need
#Text=Watch
#Text=Research/reports
#Text=Email addresses/flyers
#Text=Chairs in a circle
#Text=Evaluation form
